posts.name: Topsail Robotics
posts.cooked: Hey there, we’re team 9297 BOGO Bots and we are looking for help with our arm mechanism. The arm will be angling the shooter, similar to unqualified quokkas shooter just shorter. It is also our way of lifting the bot which will end up being around 150 lbs (arm will have to lift maybe around 225 ft-lbs) with everything (battery and bumpers) on it. Right now we are having trouble lifting even just the arm which maybe be around 50ish ft-lbs. The arm is connected to two 64 tooth sprockets on a single hex rod. The two sprockets are connected with a chain to two 10 tooth sprockets on another single hex rod. (Note sprockets are close to each other so chain may be slipping but we’re looking for the theoretical calculation) The rod with the two 10 tooth sprockets is then connected to two 16:1 gearboxes (One on each end of the rod)  with Neo motors attached to them. Can the theoretical mechanical/electrical side of this be cleared?

posts.name: Keith Farelle Cozart
posts.cooked: I would recommend going to: ReCalc and inputting these numbers. From a mechanical point of view, hex shaft is not a very strong way to transfer such high torque, but it’s likely too late in the build season to change this. I would recommend using a higher reduction gearbox and increasing the size of the 10-tooth sprocket as the chain contact is likely not great currently.

posts.name: Ari Meles-Braverman
posts.cooked: I suggest taking a look at the mechanism calculator of my AMBCalc. You can plug in the values for your arm and see if they’re feasible, and if not what to change. If you need help with it, let me know.

posts.name: Christopher149
posts.cooked:
We have a separate climber, but our similar arm has two NEOs through 100:1 MAXPlanetaries and then 64:16 chain+sprocket to the arm, or 400:1 total, compared to your ~102:1 reduction.

I don’t know how much torque the weight of our arm causes, but this reduction easily lifts our arm.

Edit: and the main pivot axle is MAXSpline with the pivot arm directly connected to the sprockets.

posts.name: Keith Farelle Cozart
posts.cooked: a 400:1 reduction going through hex will likely twist

posts.name: Christopher149
posts.cooked: Thanks, missed that. We have the sprockets bolted to the arm and our axle is MAXSpline.

posts.name: Spencer
posts.cooked: If the arm is bolted to the larger sprockets (as I would assume it is) the hex shaft should not be an issue.

posts.name: Topsail Robotics
posts.cooked:
IMG_5145 1576×2100 926 KB

IMG_5145 1576×2100 926 KB

IMG_5145 1576×2100 926 KB

Bit of a diagram if it helps( sorry don’t have picture right now, this is old photo with diagram) It isn’t bolted though is really close to the turning mechanism with spacers, and I’m not sure if we can bolt it, we might be able to if it’s important

posts.name: Spencer
posts.cooked:
Bolting it would be the best way to prevent any hex shaft twisting. If you have a light enough arm and aren’t putting too much torque on it you might be okay though. Maybe even use steel hex.

How will you be attaching the larger sprockets to the hex shaft?

posts.name: Topsail Robotics
posts.cooked: Ok thank you we’ll definitely get the sprockets connected directly if we can. We’re using a steel hex and the sprockets have the hex converter connected to them in the center which is turning the rod as of right now.

posts.name: Spencer
posts.cooked: If you’re still having trouble with lifting the arm, you can always add more gearboxes too. I think your current set-up will move faster than you expect, but it is always best to test and do what works for your team.

posts.name: Ben Edwards
posts.cooked: We have a very similar setup for our arm.  Our power is a single NEO with a 125:1 maxplanetary gearbox, spinning a 25t #35 chain sprocket with a slip clutch.  The arm is bolted to a single 46t sprocket.  Even with only one NEO current limited to 50A, we have plenty of power to move the arm. The slip clutch keeps us from breaking things if we hit something with the arm. It takes us less than a second to go from full down to full up on the arm. A NEO limited to 50A (safe continuous stall limit) develops about 11 in-lbs of torque. Multiply that by your gearbox and chain ratios, divide by the length from your arm pivot to the arm center of mass and you’ll get an Idea of how much you can lift.

posts.name: CEF
posts.cooked:
When you say you’re “having trouble,” what symptoms are you experiencing?

Assuming that your larger sprockets are either bolted directly to the arms or are adjacent to the arms, I wouldn’t expect much twisting of the hex shaft – that’s the sort of thing you see when you’re spinning a shaft at one end and trying to move something at the other end.  But, the thing you’re moving (the arm) is right next to the sprocket.

posts.name: Kara Bakowski
posts.cooked:
BOGO_Bots:

Ok thank you we’ll definitely get the sprockets connected directly if we can. We’re using a steel hex and the sprockets have the hex converter connected to them in the center which is turning the rod as of right now.

Here’s some advice I gave in another similar thread that you might want to look at.

Be warned, you will want to make that connection between the sprocket and the arm as beefy as you can, because you are now moving the load from primarily the hex shaft to primarily the bolts holding the arm/sprocket together. You’re now spreading the load between more entities (X amount of bolts instead of 1 shaft), but the cross-section of the bolts is much smaller. How those bolts are supported is really important. Here’s what it looks like when the bolts are either not supported well, or not large/strong enough:

image 840×815 49.7 KB

image 840×815 49.7 KB

image 840×815 49.7 KB

Additionally, if you are running a long shaft across the robot like that, you are running the risk of it bending because of all of the force on it, and bending makes them more likely to twist or cause other problems related to eccentricity. Keeping the arms/sprockets as close to the uprights as possible will help with this, but consider adding additional upright(s) between the arms to support it better.

Here’s one example: image 471×624 120 KB (full disclosure, we ended up sawing the bottom shaft out of ^this robot at least 3 times because it was twisted; we finally resolved the issue by adding some big constant force springs as counterbalance)

image 471×624 120 KB

image 471×624 120 KB

Better would be to add an upright immediately next to each arm on the “inside” of the robot, like this: image 1169×556 122 KB

image 1169×556 122 KB

image 1169×556 122 KB

On top of all that, you might want to add some sort of spacer between the shafts to keep them “locked” at a consistent distance. If one of the shafts bend (and therefore changes distance), you will start skipping your chain. Example:

If you STILL have issues with shafts twisting or breaking, consider changing the top axle to a dead axle instead of a live axle. This will remove nearly all torque loading from the shaft.
